engine.dice: d6 dice pool (1–4+ dice; keep the highest)
engine.mechanic: Roll a number of d6 equal to your action rating; take the highest die. 1–3: bad outcome with consequences; 4–5: success with a consequence or reduced effect; 6: full success; multiple 6s: critical success.
engine.success: Any 4+ is some kind of success. The highest die result sets the outcome tier (1–3 bad, 4/5 partial, 6 full, critical on multiple 6s). Position (controlled/risky/desperate) and effect (limited/standard/great) shape the stakes.
engine.crit: If two or more dice show 6, it is a critical success: you achieve your goal with even better effect or extra benefit as appropriate.
engine.fumble: There is no special numeric fumble; 1–3 already represents the worst outcomes. Acting from a desperate position escalates the severity of consequences and generates XP.

procedures.score: A score is a focused operation (heist, assault, occult ritual, etc.). 1) Choose a target and approach; answer engagement questions to set the starting position. 2) Play through the score using action rolls, position, and effect; use flashbacks to handle prep. 3) When the operation resolves, cut to payoff, heat, and entanglements in downtime.
procedures.downtime: Between scores, each PC gets downtime actions such as indulging vice to relieve stress, working on long-term projects, training for XP, acquiring assets, reducing heat, or healing. Downtime is more structured and less immediately dangerous than scores, but still uses rolls and can create new problems.
procedures.resistance: A PC can resist a consequence by rolling a number of d6 equal to the relevant attribute rating (Insight, Prowess, or Resolve). Take the highest die; the stress cost is 6 minus that result (0–5 stress). The consequence is reduced or avoided as described by the GM.
procedures.teamwork: PCs can assist an ally (take 1 stress to give them +1d), lead a group action (everyone rolls; best result counts, leader takes 1 stress per 1–3 result), protect a teammate (suffer their consequence instead, possibly resisting it), or set up others (improve their position or effect on follow-up actions).

fields.label: Campaign Name
fields.usage_hint: Name or tagline of the ongoing criminal saga in Doskvol or your chosen setting.

fields.label: Crew Name
fields.usage_hint: The name of the crew this scoundrel belongs to.

fields.label: Playbook
fields.usage_hint: Character type (e.g. Cutter, Hound, Leech, Lurk, Slide, Spider, Whisper, or a custom playbook).

fields.label: Alias
fields.usage_hint: Street name or handle the underworld knows them by.

fields.label: Heritage
fields.usage_hint: Cultural origin (e.g. Akoros, Skovlan, Iruvia, Severos, Tycheros). Can be invoked for heritage-related actions or XP triggers.

fields.label: Background
fields.usage_hint: Life before crime (e.g. Academic, Labor, Law, Military, Noble, Underworld).

fields.label: Look & Persona
fields.usage_hint: Short description of appearance, style, and demeanor; purely descriptive.

fields.label: Insight
fields.usage_hint: Measures analytical and observational aptitude; also used as the dice pool for Insight resistance rolls.

fields.label: Prowess
fields.usage_hint: Measures physical and martial aptitude; used as the dice pool for Prowess resistance rolls.

fields.label: Resolve
fields.usage_hint: Measures willpower and social force; used as the dice pool for Resolve resistance rolls.

fields.label: Hunt
fields.usage_hint: Tracking targets, laying ambushes, and long-range marksmanship (Insight).

fields.label: Study
fields.usage_hint: Careful research, examination of documents or objects, academic analysis (Insight).

fields.label: Survey
fields.usage_hint: Scanning surroundings, anticipating trouble, spotting opportunities (Insight).

fields.label: Tinker
fields.usage_hint: Building, repairing, modifying, or sabotaging mechanical / spark-craft devices (Insight).

fields.label: Finesse
fields.usage_hint: Manual dexterity, picking pockets and locks, acrobatics, and precise dueling (Prowess).

fields.label: Prowl
fields.usage_hint: Sneaking, climbing, and moving unseen through shadows and back alleys (Prowess).

fields.label: Skirmish
fields.usage_hint: Close combat in brawls and melee fights, trading blows with blades and fists (Prowess).

fields.label: Wreck
fields.usage_hint: Demolition, sabotage, smashing through obstacles, and causing mayhem (Prowess).

fields.label: Attune
fields.usage_hint: Opening your mind to the ghost field, spirits, and arcane power (Resolve).

fields.label: Command
fields.usage_hint: Intimidation, threats, and forceful leadership, especially over gangs or minions (Resolve).

fields.label: Consort
fields.usage_hint: Socializing with friends and contacts to gain information, favors, or access (Resolve).

fields.label: Sway
fields.usage_hint: Deception, persuasion, and argument to influence others with guile or charm (Resolve).

fields.label: Stress
fields.usage_hint: Nine-box track representing reserves of grit and strain. Spend stress to push yourself, assist, resist consequences, or activate some abilities. When you fill the last box, you take trauma and clear all stress.

fields.label: Trauma Conditions
fields.usage_hint: Permanent trauma tags such as Cold, Haunted, Obsessed, Paranoid, Reckless, Soft, Unstable, Vicious. At four trauma conditions, the character must retire or be removed from play.

fields.label: Harm (Lesser)
fields.usage_hint: Level 1 harm entries (e.g. Battered, Drained, Scared). When relevant, they usually impose reduced effect.

fields.label: Harm (Moderate)
fields.usage_hint: Level 2 harm entries (e.g. Deep Cut, Concussion, Panicked). When applicable, they usually impose –1d to rolls.

fields.label: Harm (Severe)
fields.usage_hint: Level 3 harm entries (e.g. Broken Leg, Shot in Chest). Typically leaves the character incapacitated unless they push themselves or get help.

fields.label: Armor Uses
fields.usage_hint: Three boxes representing regular armor, heavy armor, and special armor. Each can be marked once per score to reduce or avoid harm as described by abilities and items.

fields.label: Load Level
fields.usage_hint: Chosen load for a score (e.g. Light, Normal, Heavy). Controls how much gear can be marked from the playbook list and how conspicuous the character appears.

fields.label: Carried Items
fields.usage_hint: Items selected from the playbook’s gear list or crew/setting gear. Each entry can note name, load cost, and any tags such as fine, unusual, or illicit.

fields.label: Special Abilities
fields.usage_hint: Playbook abilities, including Veteran advances. Each item should include at least a name and short rules text.

fields.label: Vice Type
fields.usage_hint: One of the core vice types (Faith, Gambling, Luxury, Obligation, Pleasure, Stupor, Weird). Determines how the character relieves stress in downtime.

fields.label: Vice Purveyor
fields.usage_hint: The specific person or place that provides the character’s vice (e.g. a gambling den, a cult shrine, a drug dealer).

fields.label: Close Friends
fields.usage_hint: List of friendly NPC contacts, often from the playbook list, with optional notes on how they help or complicate scores.

fields.label: Rivals
fields.usage_hint: List of hostile or competitive NPCs tied to the character’s past or current operations.

fields.label: Heritage & Background Details
fields.usage_hint: Short notes on culture, upbringing, and background anecdotes. Can be invoked for XP triggers when expressed in play.

fields.label: Beliefs & Drives
fields.usage_hint: What the character cares about, their ambitions, and values—fuel for XP triggers and roleplay.

fields.label: XP – Insight
fields.usage_hint: Attribute XP track for Insight. Mark XP when rolling desperate Insight actions or from end-of-session awards; at 6 XP, clear the track and add a dot to a linked action.

fields.label: XP – Prowess
fields.usage_hint: Attribute XP track for Prowess. Works like Insight XP but for Prowess actions.

fields.label: XP – Resolve
fields.usage_hint: Attribute XP track for Resolve. Works like Insight XP but for Resolve actions.

fields.label: XP – Playbook
fields.usage_hint: Playbook XP track. End-of-session triggers and training can fill this; at 8 XP, clear the track and choose a new special ability (including Veteran options).

fields.label: Coin
fields.usage_hint: Immediately spendable wealth. Limited by what a character can carry; excess should be banked in stash or invested fictionally.

fields.label: Stash
fields.usage_hint: Long-term savings that determine the character’s retirement quality when they leave play.

rules.name: Action Rolls and Results
rules.content: To overcome an obstacle, choose an action rating and roll a number of d6 equal to its dots. Take the highest die: 1–3 is a bad outcome with serious consequences, 4–5 is success with a consequence or reduced effect, 6 is full success, and multiple 6s is a critical success with extra benefit.

rules.name: Position and Effect
rules.content: Every action roll has a position—Controlled, Risky, or Desperate—and an effect level—Limited, Standard, or Great (sometimes Extreme or None). Position defines how dangerous failure is; effect defines how much you accomplish on a success. Players and GM can negotiate tradeoffs, such as worse position for better effect.

rules.name: Stress, Pushing, and Assists
rules.content: PCs can take 2 stress to push themselves, gaining +1d, +1 effect level, or acting despite severe harm. They can take 1 stress to assist an ally, giving them +1d and sharing the risk. Stress is a finite track; filling it leads to trauma.

rules.name: Resistance Rolls and Trauma
rules.content: When a consequence occurs, a PC may resist it by rolling dice equal to an attribute rating (Insight, Prowess, or Resolve). The stress cost is 6 minus the highest die (0–5). Resistance often reduces the consequence, and may negate it. If stress is filled when more is marked, the character immediately takes a trauma condition and is removed from the current scene.

rules.name: Harm Levels and Recovery
rules.content: Harm comes in four levels. Lesser (level 1) usually imposes reduced effect; Moderate (2) typically inflicts –1d; Severe (3) usually incapacitates you unless you push yourself or get help; Fatal (4) is catastrophic and can mean death or permanent change. Healing in downtime uses recovery rolls and may require multiple segments on a clock to fully clear harm.

rules.name: Devil’s Bargains
rules.content: Before rolling, a player may accept a devil’s bargain: take an extra die in exchange for a cost that will occur regardless of the roll’s result. Costs might include extra heat, collateral damage, angered factions, harmed friends, or future complications. Bargains stack with pushing but cannot be canceled after the roll.

rules.name: Teamwork Options
rules.content: During a score, PCs can Assist for +1d at 1 stress, Lead a Group Action so everyone rolls and only the best counts (leader takes 1 stress for each 1–3 rolled), Protect to take an ally’s consequence (possibly resisting it), or Set Up a teammate to grant improved position or effect on their following roll.

rules.name: Scores, Downtime, and Free Play
rules.content: Play cycles through free play (roleplay and setup), scores (focused operations resolved in a few rolls with flashbacks for prep), and downtime (vice, healing, projects, training, and crew management). Scores generate coin and heat; downtime reduces stress and advances long-term goals.

rules.name: XP Triggers and Advancement
rules.content: Characters earn XP when they roll desperate actions, when they express beliefs, drives, heritage, or background, and when they address challenges using their playbook’s methods. XP may be assigned to attribute tracks (to gain new action dots) or to the playbook track (to gain new special abilities).

rules.name: Heat, Wanted, and Entanglements
rules.content: Each score generates Heat with the authorities depending on noise, violence, and witnesses. Accumulated Heat raises the crew’s Wanted level over time. After downtime, an entanglement is rolled based on Wanted level, introducing new trouble such as reprisals, investigations, or arrests.
